2 Four hydes made one knight's see: The relief of a barony was twelve
times greater than that of a knight's fee; whence we may conjecture its
usual value. Spelm. Gloss. in verb. Feodum. There were 243,600 hydes in
England, and 60,215 knights fees; whence it is evident that there were a
little more than four hydes in each knlght's fee.

I Sometimes the historians mention the people, populus, as a part of the
patliament: But they always mean the laity, in opposition to the clergy.
Sometimes, the word, commynitas, is found; but it always means communitas
baronagii. These points are clearly proved by Dr. Brady. There is also
mention sometimes made of a crowd or multitude that thronged into the
great council on particular interesting occasions; but as deputies from boroughs
are never gnee spoke of, the proof, that they had not then any existence, be-
comes the more ertain apd undeniable. These never could make a crowd, as
they niust have had a regular place assigned them, if they had made a regular
pet of the lepissative hody. Ther were only13 boroughs who received
writs of summons from Edward I.

d We learn from the extracts given us of Domesday by Brady in his
Treatise of Boroughs, that almost all the boroughs of England had suffered in
the shock of the Conquest, and had decayed extremely between the death o
the Confessor, and the time when Domesday was framed.

" M. Paris, p. 638. The same author, a few pages before, makes Ri-
chard's treasures amount to little more than half the sum, p. 634. The king's
dissipations and expences, throughout his whole reign, according to the same
author, had amounted only to about 940,000 marks, p. 638.
t The sums mentioned by ancient authors, who were almost all monks
are often improbable, and never consistent. But we know from an infallible
authority, the poblic remonstrance to the council of Lyons, that the king's
revenues were below 60,000 marks a year: His brother therefore could never
have been master of 700,000 marks; especially as he did not sell his estates
in England, as we learn from the same author: And we hear afterwards of
his ordering all his woods to be eut, in order to satiesy the rapacity of the
German princes: His son succeeded to the earldom of Cornwal and his other

I Statutes at large, p. 6. k We learn from Cicero's orations
against Verres, Iib. iii. cap. 84, 92. that the price of corn in Sieily was,
during the praetorship of Sacerdos, sive Denarii a Mosius; during that
of Verres, which immediately succeeded, only two Sesterces: That is,
ten times lower; a presumption, or rather a proof, of the very bad state of
tillage in ancient times. So also Knyghton, P. 2444.

I This tax was a livre upon a hearth; and it was imagined, that this im-
position would have yielded 1,200,000 livres a year, which suppsses so many
hearths in the provinces possessed by the English. But such loose conjectures
have commonly no manner of authority, much less in such ignorant times.
There is a strang instance of it in the present reign. The house of commons
granted the king a tax of twenty-two shillings on each parish, supposing that
the an ount of the whole would be 50,000 pounds. But they were found to
be in mistake of near five to one. Cotton, p. 3. And the council assumed
the power of augmenting the tax upon each parish.

The pay of a man at arms was quadruple. We may therefore conclude, that
the numerous armies, mentioned by historians in those times, consisted chiefly
of ragamussins, who followed the camp, and lived by plunder. Edward's
army before Calais consisted of 31,094 men; yet its pay for sixteen months
was only 127,201 pounds. Brady, ibid.
d Commodities seem to have risen since the Conquest. Instead of belng
ten times cheaper than at present, they were in the age of Edward III. only
three or sour times. This change seems to have thken place in a great mes
sure since Edward I. The allowance granted by Edward III. to the eafl of
Murray, then a prisoner in Nottingham castle, is one pound a week; whoress
the bishop of St. Andrews, the primate of Scotland, had only six-pence a day
allowed him by Edward I.
